Variation Example: A goose builds a house of feathers, a hog one of stone. A wolf (bear) blows the goose’s house down & eats her. He cannot blow down the hog’s house. He tries to lure the hog but the hog outwits him: e.g. the wolf suggests they steal apples together (go to the market) but the hog goes earlier so that the wolf cannot eat him. Finally the wolf tries to get into the house through the chimney. He is burned or scald ed with boiling water. Or, three pigs build one house of straw, one of sticks, & one of iron. The wolf destroys the first two houses & eats the pigs but the third pig is able to outwit him.

Classifications: The Wolf Flees from the Wolf-head
Variation Example: Domestic animals (sheep, donkey) find a sack & the head (bones) of a dangerous animal (wolf, tiger). They meet another wolf & make him believe that they have killed one of his kind. The wolf flees in terror

This tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A donkey brags to a lion about his abilities & is challenged to press water out of a piece of wood (offers to beat water from the ground with his hoof). When the donkey urinates from the effort, the lion takes him for the stronger animal. (2) A lion pulls down the top of a tree & challenges a donkey to do the same thing. The donkey is thrown into a bush where he falls on a rabbit & kills it. After that the donkey boasts about his abilities ( 125C*). (with human actors). (3) A donkey impresses a lion by catching a fish in his ear while he takes a bath in the river.
A wolf (tiger) wants to eat a sheep (goat). The sheep pretends to eat wolves & chases the wolf away.

A he-goat, a cat & a ram run away from their owners. When they meet some wolves & a bear, they take refuge in a tree. While they are in the tree, the wolves threaten to eat them. The he-goat falls in fright on a wolf & injures him with his horns. The wolves run away.

Classifications: The Wolf Induces the Goat to come down from a Cliff & Devours it
Variation Example: In some variants the goat refuses to come.

Classifications: The Goat Eats in the Garden & is Caught
Variation Example: The fox says, “If your sense were as long as your beard, you would have looked for an exit as well as an entrance”.
Two Sheep Kill a Fox who licked up the blood they spilled in a fight.
When a wolf watches this he says, “This is not fair. If I were to do that they would say I was eating it.”

Classifications: Animals in New Quarters (Bremen Town Musicians)
Variation Example: (Bremen Town Musicians) Donkey, dog, cat & rooster are ill-treated by their owners because they are too old to work. They run away & find a lonely house in the forest. Thieves come & begin to divide their money. The four animals climb on one another’s backs & cry all at once. The thieves (robbers) are frightened & run away, leaving the money there. When the thieves try to come back the animals hide in various parts of the house & attack them with their characteristic powers. The four animals drive the thieves away & live happily ever after.

Domestic animals (ox, rooster, ram, pig) escape from their owner & want to build a house. In some variants only one of them builds a house for the winter & the others think they do not need one. The animal with the house nevertheless must give them shelter.
Domestic animals (goat, ram, cat, donkey, dog, rooster) flee from their home. In the night a pack of wolves wants to eat them, but they defend themselves successfully.

Classifications: Animals in Company of a Man
Variation Example: Donkey, goat, dog & cat look for a new home. They find an old woman (man) & promise to work for her.In some variants they cheat the old person, & in other variants they help her.

Domestic animals flee because they are treated badly. To start a fire, the cat advises the goat to wind some birch bark around his head like horns & to have a fight with the ram. The bark begins to burn. A bear warms himself at the fire. When they are attacked by wolves, they defend themselves successfully.

Classifications: Tiger as False Friend to the Cow
Variation Example: A tiger & a cow become friends & both bear offspring. The tiger drinks water downstream from the cow, decides her flesh would be sweet, & kills & devours her. The calf flees. The cub of the tiger is ashamed of its mother & accompanies the calf on adventures.

Classifications: Goat Admires his Horns in the Water
Variation Example: The Goat Admires His Horns in the Water, & says to himself that he does not have to fear the wolf. The wolf stands behind him & asks what he was saying. The goat answers, “Nothing – people who have drunk too much say foolish things”.

Classifications: The Goat Carries the Snake over a Stream
Variation Example: A goat (turtle, fox) carries a snake (scorpion, crocodile) over a river. When they have crossed it, the snake kills the goat: Nature always asserts itself. In some variants the goat kills the snake.

Classifications: The Mouse Makes a Boat of a Bread-Crust
Variation Example: She takes other animals & birds into the boat & it capsizes. The animals quarrel.

Classifications: The Fox Stumbles over a Violin
Variation Example: When he is chased by dogs, a fox stumbles over a violin & says, “What a fine opportunity to dance if I had the time!”

Classifications: Wolf Surprises Pig in Apple Tree
Variation Example: A wolf sees a pig in an apple tree. He promises not to eat the pig if the pig will throw him one his hams. The pig throws down a piece of thorny wood instead, which cuts the wolf’s throat.

A cat says she will confess her sins. Other animals (rabbit, wolf, fox) want to do the same & accompany her. At a ditch the cat says, “He who can cross it safely shall be without sin”. [M114]. Only the cat crosses the ditch; the other animals fall in & the cat laughs at them.

Classifications: The Filthy Hog & the Clean Fish
Variation Example: A fish laughs at a hog because it is so filthy. The hog says to the fish, “People will spit when they eat you, whereas in my case all will lick their fingers”.

In return for his freedom, a bird (fox) gives a man three pieces of advice: first, “never try to reach the unattainable”, second “Do not regret a thing that is past”, & third, “Never believe what is beyond belief”. The bird tells him a lie. The man regrets having freed the bird, & the bird says that the man learned nothing from the advice. In some (parodistic) variants a fox promises three pieces of advice to a ferryman. As they cross the river the fox offers two trivial aphorisms. When they reach the bank, the fox, as the third piece of advice, tells the ferryman that he will never get rich if he transports everyone so cheaply.
A farmer agrees to take in a frog for the winter, & in return it gives him three trite counsels.

Classifications: Man Teaches Wild Animal to Play Fiddle
Variation Example: A wild animal (bear, wolf) sees a man playing the fiddle in the forest, or a man is locked up with a dangerous animal (lion, tiger, wolf). He plays on his fiddle for the animal, who asks to learn how to play the instrument. The man says he must cut his claws & catches the animal’s paws in a cleft tree. Similarly the man tricks other animals. After the animals get free, they try in vain to take revenge.
A lion in love asks to marry the daughter of a farmer, who tells him he must give up his teeth & his claws. He allows them to be cut, but then he is helpless against the farmer’s abuse.

A plowman punishes animals that disturb him in his work. He burns a bear (wolf) with red-hot iron, tears off the legs of a crow (magpie) & pricks a gadfly with a blade of grass. The animals then watch the man with his girlfriend & interpret his behavior accordingly. The bear says: “He is drawing a pattern on her sides”. The crow says, “He is twisting her leg”. The gadfly says, “He is sticking a stalk of grass into her backside”.
At a signal from her husband, a wife scalds a wolf with boiling water. The next day, the man is attacked by the wolf. He escapes by shouting, “Pour, Catherine!” The wolf flees.

Classifications: The Gelding of the Bear & the Fetching of Salve
Variation Example: A man tells a bear that the horse is strong because it is gelded. The bear has the man geld him to make him strong. The next day the bear wants to geld the man. The man substitutes his wife to pretend they have been already castrated. The bear is shocked by the “wound” of the woman & goes for salve. A fox guards the woman, but she drives him away with her farts.

A man in anger calls his horse “bear-food”. A bear comes & threatens to eat the horse. A fox agrees to help the man against the bear in return for geese. The fox goes into the forest & imitates the barking of dogs. The bear is intimidated & killed. The man pretends to go for the geese but instead brings dogs back in his bag. The dogs chase the fox to his hole. Here the fox asks his feet, eyes, ears, & tail how they helped him in his flight. His tail admits that it did not help. As a punishment the fox sticks out his tail & is attacked by dogs. In some variants a rabbit asks his members about their help in his flight

A man rescues a snake (wolf, bear, tiger) from a trap. In return the snake seeks to kill the rescuer. Other animals are asked if a good deed should be repayed with a bad one. The fox, as judge, asks the snake to show how it was trapped. The snake is tricked into captivity. In some variants a man warms a cold snake. The ungrateful snake bites the man & he dies

A shepherd pulls a thorn out of a lion’s paw. When the shepherd is thrown as a punishment into a pit of lions, the lion recognises him & licks his hand instead of tearing him to pieces. The emperor releases both. Or, a bone is removed from an animal’s (wolf, tiger, bear) throat, & later the animal shows gratitude to the rescuer.
A man rescues a lion (often from a struggle with a dragon) & out of gratitude it follows the man for his whole life, even to his grave.
This misc. type comprises various tales dealing with a person (man, woman) who helps a snake (e.g. in a battle or to give birth). The snake rewards the person (with gold or money).

Classifications: The Boy & the Bear in Pit
Variation Example: A boy falls into a pit on top of a bear, & helps him to get out of the pit. The bear helps the boy & shows him where to find money.

A wolf (lion, bear) boasts about being stronger than a man. The fox wants to convince him that men are dangerous. They see a boy, & the fox explains that he will be a man later. When they meet an old man, the fox says this was a man but is no longer one. Then they see an armed hunter. The wolf approaches, but the man shots & stabs him with a sabre. Later the wolf tells the fox he could have defeated the man if he did not spit fire & attack him with a sharp rib.

A young lion, warned by his parents to shun man, asks other large animals if they are man. They answer that they are only the ill-treated servants of men. He meets a man & is scornful of him, but the man tricks him into entering a cage & leaves him to starve. Or, the man tricks the lion into placing his claws in a cleft of a tree where he is trapped.

A sparrow whose children were lost meets them again & asks how they survived. Three of them tell where they lived, & the sparrow praises them. The fourth lives in a church & the old sparrow admires his wise decision.
The animals want to hide themselves from men. The wild beasts hide in the forest, the birds in the air, the fish in the water. However, man catches them all with his gun, his noose & his fishing-rod.

Classifications: The Wild Animals on the Sleigh
Variation Example: Other animals ask the fox for a ride on his sleigh, which breaks. To repair it, the animals bring unsatis-factory material from the forest. When the fox goes for good material they eat the horse & build a dummy to replace it.
